CalARP Risk Management Plan
Air Products and Chemicals, Inc.
Sacramento, California
June 2004



    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.      Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

At this facility, we manufacture gaseous and liquid hydrogen.  Hydrogen, in the amounts 
handled by our facility, is considered hazardous by the EPA.  It is our policy to adhere to 
all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  In addition, Corporate Practice 
1002A, Emergency Response Program, and 1003A Planning for Emergencies, 
specifically highlight the Air Products' commitment of being prepared for and 
responding promptly and appropriately to emergency events. Air Products manages the 
safety of the regulated processes by means of operating procedures, equipment testing 
and inspections, safety devices (e.g., alarms, shutdowns, instrumentation, relief devices) 
inherent in the design of this facility and other controls and systems such as the site 
security system, communications system, fire control system, and flammable gas 
monitoring system, designed and used to help prevent and control accidental releases of 
hazardous chemicals.  Safe work practices and training of our personnel supplement the 
inherent safe design of the plant.

Our emergency response program is based upon OSHA's HAZWOPER regulation.  The 
emergency response plan includes procedures for the notification of the local fire 
authority and Hazardous Materials unit so that appropriate measures can be taken by 
local emergency responders to control accidental releases.

This document has been prepared in accordance with the EPA's Risk Management Plan 
regulation (40 CFR, Part 68). The substances and processes considered during the 
preparation of this RMP and the scenarios described were selected based on criteria 
established in the regulation.

2.    The stationary source and regulated substances handled:

The Sacramento facility mailing address is 5025 83rd Street, Sacramento, California and it 
is

located at 38 31' 47" N and 121 23' 56" W.  The facility is owned and operated by Air 
Products Manufacturing Corporation, a wholly owned facility of Air Products and 
Chemicals, Inc.  The facility has the following registrations: RMP ID 100000001972, 
EPA ID CAD082023665 and a Dunns # 003002070.  The site's manager and emergency 
contact is Race Cargile (916) 381-1776.  

The primary purpose of this facility is the manufacturing of gaseous and liquid hydrogen. 
Gaseous hydrogen is used by our customer in their manufacturing process. Gaseous 
hydrogen is produced in the reformer process (See Reformer Process below) and 
transmitted to the customer via pipeline. The pipeline is connected to a 20,000 gallon 
liquid hydrogen backup tank that supplies the pipeline when the reformer is off-line.  
Gaseous hydrogen exists in various stages of purity at the Sacramento plant, depending 
upon where it is in the manufacturing process.  Ultimately the product gaseous hydrogen 
sent to P&G is pure hydrogen. 

Liquid hydrogen is also produced from the hydrogen gas taken from the reformer 
process. Liquid hydrogen is produced by passing  hydrogen gas through a series of 
compression, cooling, and expansion steps. The liquid hydrogen is stored in two 70,000 
gallon and one 20,000 gallon liquid hydrogen tanks.  Liquid hydrogen is loaded into 
highway tankers and shipped to various off-site customers.  Liquid hydrogen stored on 
site is pure hydrogen.

REFORMER PROCESS: Hydrocarbon based gases (natural gas or methane) are received 
by our plant via pipeline and used as our feedstock.  The feedstock is then compressed 
and "cracked" in our reformer (furnace).  By exposing the feedstock to a catalyst in the 
presence of heat (approximately 1,500 degrees F.) and steam, a chemical reaction takes 
place that converts the feedstock into hydrogen, carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide.  
The carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide is then separated from the hydrogen in 
adsorbers.  The pure hydrog

en is then compressed and delivered to customers or the 
hydrogen liquefier via pipe. 

The regulated substance handled at this facility is the flammable gas  hydrogen.   The site 
stores approximately 160,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen in two 70,000 gallon tanks and 
one 20,000 gallon tank.  This is equivalent to approximately 95,000 pounds of liquid 
hydrogen at 14.7 psia.  .  The site also has a small amount of gaseous hydrogen 
(approximately 200 pounds) contained in the operating process equipment and lines.



3.      The general accidental release prevention program and specific prevention 
steps:

The facility developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA's 
Accidental Release Prevention Plan, the California Accidental Release Prevention 
Program (CalARP), and OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  This 
facility was designed and constructed to comply with applicable state and industry codes.

As part of the basic prevention plan a formal HAZOP was performed considering hazards 
such as toxic release, fire, explosion, runaway reactions, over pressurization, corrosion, 
overfilling, process contamination, equipment failure, loss of cooling, heating, electrical 
power, and instrument air, and earthquakes.  All PHA and pre-startup recommendations 
were identified and have been addressed since the initial CalARP program was put in 
place.

Design and operations process controls used to control potential process related incidents 
include vents, relief valves, check valves, manual shutoffs, automatic shutoffs, interlocks, 
alarms and procedures, grounding equipment, rupture disks and excess flow devices.  
Mitigation systems include the firewater monitors and deluge systems.  Process area 
detectors are employed to monitor system operations.  Design features employed to 
prevent and/or mitigate possible release events include bullards (bump posts) to protect 
process and storage equipment and structural design to meet Seismic Zone 4 sta

ndards.

The Sacramento facility employs both company wide and site-specific operating 
procedures to assure safe and proper plant operations.  In addition to plant operations 
training all personnel complete the company Environmental, Health and Safety training 
and maintain competence through regularly scheduled refresher courses and program 
updates.  A mechanical integrity program has been developed and is in place for the 
Sacramento facility for all RMP covered process systems.  The Sacramento facility 
participates in the Production Systems Organization Facility Change Notice 
(Management of Change) program assuring the proper level of technical review for all 
proposed facility changes.  Compliance audits of RMP systems and all EH&S systems by 
our Corporate Process Safety Group and the Corporate Assurance Group.  All incidents 
that could have a safety and/or environmental impact are entered into the Corporate 
Incident Tracking System and evaluated both by plant and corporate personnel.  Apollo 
Root Cause Analyses are performed on any serious incidents or near misses and are 
reviewed by the PSO Incident Review Committee comprised of senior operations 
management.  All operations employees are engaged directly and continuously through 
the company's Basic Safety Process.  Hot work permits are controlled under Section 5 ? 
Safe Systems of Work, in the Air Products Global EH&S standards.  All contractors 
contractor firms are evaluated prior to employment both in terms of technical competence 
and safety performance.  All contract workers participate in safety indoctrination training 
before being allowed to work on-site.


4.      Five-year accident history:

There have been no accidents involving or accidental releases of flammable gas that 
resulted in any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site 
deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental 
damage in the past five years.

5.      The

emergency response program:

The facility's emergency response program is based upon OSHA's HAZWOPER 
standard.  At this site, employees are trained to recognize emergencies and initiate 
emergency response from outside agencies.  They have been trained to OSHA's First 
Responder Awareness Level.  The employees receive annual refresher training in their 
role in the emergency plan.  Emergency response activities have also been coordinated 
with the City of Sacramento Fire Department  Hazmat Team  for emergencies related to 
the hydrogen process.  Periodic site meetings  are conducted with the Fire Department  to 
review the effectiveness of our emergency procedures.

6.      Planned changes to improve safety:

The facility resolves recommendations from PHAs and Incident Investigations, some of which
may result in modifications to the plant design and operating procedures.  A Security and 
Vulnerability Assessment by an independent auditor was conducted in May of 2003.
Implementation of the resulting recommendation is currently underway.  Currently there
are no other facility changes planned.
